Posts.Title: Partial or total lymph node clearance?

Posts.Content: I had mx and full clearance in March, followed by RT. The advice I was given, was to get back to doing all the things I was doing as soon as I felt comfortable with it. My job does mean I quite often graze or nick my hand or arm, so the savlon is never too far away. I carry crates of equipment, and shoot arrows. Not had any problems. I did opt to have the artery invasion for an angiogram in the mx side (non-dominant), as I couldn't risk picking up something heavy without thinking for 2 weeks after the procedure if I had it in the dominant arm. Not had any issues there either. I did some reading up, there have been some trials done which indicate that load bearing exercise gradually increased is actually beneficial. It was proving beneficial to subjects who already had lymphedema as well. I have noticed, being on light duties after the angiogram, that if I don't do some stretching exercises (normally taken care of in the course of my work) my shoulder stiffens up and aches. So do keep up with the exercises, they are invaluable for getting mobility back and maintaining it. xx

Posts.Title: SO IT TOOK ME A YEAR......BUT

Posts.Content: Hey Ann anni69 - well done - you're half way through it!! I think your AC is the same as the EC I had. I worked all the way through, and didn't have much nausea. I had acid reflux instead! The fatigue I remember well!! Tax was easier in a lot of ways. I wasn't fighting constipation which was a definite plus. The side effects didn't kick in until day 3/4. Had it wed and crashed fri night. The bone and joint aches were the worst. Also had dizzy faint spells on the sat. Keep on top of the pain meds!! By the mon I was ok ish and back at work.  The steroid dose is much higher for Tax, so the crash is harder. The bad taste and yucky mouth was worse. And the fatigue. I was having to stop and rest during the day so I didn't fall asleep at the wheel! On the plus side - I competed at the Southern Counties Archery Champs 3 1/2 weeks after finishing chemo, took a bronze in the champs and shot the 4th highest score in the team round after.  So it's doable. Pace yourself, and stay on top of pain meds. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Megestrol for hot flushes but now bleeding

Posts.Content: Hey Glblakeley89 Not the pill, but I am back on HRT after my treatment. HER2+ (low) and ER0/PR0, mx/anc and implant. The main thing is the ER/PR score of your cancer. As you were TN, they will be low. However, unless they were actually zero, there will always be an element of risk with the pill. I went through my GP, who was very understanding, and he wrote to my oncologist who recommended a specific type of hrt for me. I'm sure others will be along who are using other types of contraceptive, such as the coil. Just a heads up though. They never get ALL of the breast tissue with a mastectomy. There will always be some left. So do be vigilant to any changes in your scars etc. Hope that helps xx

Posts.Title: Having a witness

Posts.Content: Hi clover3 - I'll add another vote for what a great sister you are!! I was diagnosed last year (day after 49th birthday!), HER2+ and ER/PR0. I had lymph node involvement and a 40mm x 30mm lump, with assorted other calcifications. Chemo was 3xEC and 4xT finished in Feb, then left mx and node clearance with immediate implant. They got clear margins and saved the nipple - not that I can feel it, which is a pain when it itches..... I had 15 RT in May, and had 12/18 Herceptin today. As far as I know I'm cancer free, just mopping up any strays with H. Also getting bone strengthening infusion every 6 months as I'm now post menopause. While it wasn't much fun, I did manage to work through chemo (I'd have gone nuts staying home!!) and had 2 weeks off for surgery. RT was harder, as it's so intense going in every day. It's doable. One minute at a time some days though! Hugs to both of you xx

Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hey Lamonsea - you really have had an awful time of it. I can't even begin to imagine all the stress the delays have caused you. That said, delaying chemo any further is probably not the best plan. It is doable. I worked all the way through chemo. We all get SOME of the side effects, but very few get ALL of them. And there are meds for most of them. I was too young for mammograms, and by the time I found a lump it was in the nodes. But they did get all of it. I had chemo before surgery. It is possible to delay one or two of the cycles by a week. I delayed one myself due to work commitments, and another was delayed due to low bloods. My work involves going into people's houses. Where there were kids with infections. Businesses, where there were people with infections. If you are careful with hygiene and use hand gel at all times, and avoid getting too close to outsiders with infections, you should be able to manage it. I never picked up one. Had a couple of colds, but nothing that delayed chemo. Christmas was a washout for me last year - I had chemo that week and was on my crap weekend for Christmas. Hubby cooked, I couldn't eat much of it. He was emotional, worrying it would be our last one. We managed. Our families are both in South Africa. So no physical support. We managed. Talk to the kids - they cope better than we think they will. But they will react to our worrying. Be honest, they can tell a half truth better than we can. Trust the girls to step up - they may surprise you. 5 or 6 months of crap. Yes, it's not pleasant. But it passes. Surely it's worth it, to hopefully get a lot more years? I'm sure you could use a few hugs - so here's one to start you off. xx

Posts.Title: Coloured hearts on Facebook

Posts.Content: Hiya. Sorry you find yourself here, but welcome, and we will try to answer your questions whenever you have them. I'm sure other more knowledgeable folk will be along soon, but in the meanwhile ..... I can't answer the lobular bit, but invasive means it has grown outside the lobes. ER8 - oestrogen strongly positive, PR7 - same for progesterone. That means you will have to take Tamoxifen or similar after surgery. HER2 is a genetic abnormality which causes cells to overmultiply. Not the hereditary one. If that is negative, then you may escape chemo if there is no lymph node involvement. If it is positive then you get chemo and Herceptin which is a targeted biological therapy for HER2+. I had Invasive Ductal, ER0 PR0 HER2+ with lymph node involvement. So I had 7x chemo, mastectomy and full node clearance, currently having radiotherapy and still on Herceptin till December. It is tough, but it is doable. Breast cancer in general is very treatable these days, so try not to worry too much. Once they have all your results back they will give you a plan. They do do some further scans sometimes, just to check they've got it right. Please stay in touch on here, and offload or ask questions as much as you need to. Good luck xx

Posts.Content: Hi JoDec There's quite a few of us who had chemo first. Two reasons they do it that way - the first is to shrink the lump enough to make a lumpectomy possible, and the second is when it's an aggressive form like I had (HER2+ Grade 3) with spread to lymph nodes they want to hammer it as quickly as possible. I was diagnosed 20 Sep and first chemo was 12 Oct, and I had contrast CT and bone scan in between. So it all happened pretty quickly. Have you had a look at the monthly Chemo Club yet? You can find the August one here, and there will be folks at about the same stage as you to help each other through, There is a link on the first page to a blog with tips and advice. All the waiting is wearing isn't it? Once you get going you will feel better mentally. Use the time to get stuff done you might not have the energy for while on chemo. Like a spring clean, freezer meals and so on. Which will keep you busy and your mind away from worrying for a while. Chemo isn't a lot of fun, but it is doable. Some days it's one minute at a time. You've got this. Hugs xx

Posts.Content: Hi @treacle321 Welcome to the community - not that any of us particularly wanted to be here. We hope your stay will be short - in the best possible way!! Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Hi volvox167  Welcome to the community. Sounds like you need a few hugs, so here you go. Your fears have resonated with me. A year ago I was wondering the same things. I install and service intruder alarms, so very physical. I am also an archer, and was knocking on the door of county team when I was diagnosed. I decided on immediate implant reconstruction, as I didn't want a long recovery time or depletion of my back muscles. (Similar muscle use to rowing I think). I already knew I had lymph involvement at the start. So it was a one stop shop surgery wise - all off and out. Mine was HER2+, so I had chemo first. I was offered a PICC line, but would not have been able to shoot. They accommodated me and I had a Portacath, which is all internal, and after a week there was no restriction on what I could do. Unfortunately I missed the Indoor Nationals as I had chemo 4 days before, and there was no way I could do it. I did work all the way through chemo, on light (ish) duties. I managed to shoot near to my best scores at the Southern Counties Champs 3 1/2 weeks after finishing chemo, and took a bronze.  I had 2 weeks off work after surgery, but no shooting for 6 weeks, to let the internal stitching heal. I had full mobility in 10 days (once the drains were out). Unfortunately I was unlucky, and now have chemo induced heart failure. With the accompanying low energy levels. But the meds are doing their thing, and I'm getting back out on the field again. It is all doable. Not always easy. You do have to pace yourself, and be kind to yourself. I think, for me, continuing to work and shoot helped me mentally and emotionally to cope with treatment. SOME things HAD to stay normal, or I would have gone nuts!! Sorry for the long post, I just wanted reassure you that many women get through this without most of the ghastly side effects. Those who post on here are those who did suffer, not those who didn't. We all get some SE, but very few get all of them. Your physical fitness will be of enormous benefit to you. And the peak condition of your shoulder muscles will aid your recovery from surgery. You've got this. And we've got you. More hugs xx

Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi monicanatura A warm welcome to the community - the club none of us particularly wanted to join. That sounds pretty confusing for you. A change from DCIS to Invasive is not uncommon, and there may be a terminology issue there. DCIS is Ductal Carcinoma in Situ - in other words contained within the milk ducts. When it grows through the duct wall, it becomes invasive or IDC. Inflammatory is a whole other thing though, so good that you're getting a second opinion on that. HER2+ is a genetic disorder, where the HER2 receptors start growing wildly. Not hereditary, they don't know why. This can be a factor in all types of breast cancer, the same as hormone receptors (ER/PR). The results for HER2 can often take longer than the others, which is why the dx can change. Mine did. I was originally triple negative, then the HER2 results came back weakly positive. I hope that is all about as clear as mud It sounds like the inflammatory bit is the outlier here, which the new oncologist will be able to clear up for you. It sounds like chemo is doing it's thing for you. Mine shrunk by about half on EC chemo. I guess you're in need of a hug or two, so here you go.

Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: I think it's a case of "everything in moderation". If we are to believe the experts nothing is good for us anyway. No margarine iin this house either, it's butter all the way. I've always eaten relatively healthily, just never enough really. If I'm busy I forget to eat, if I'm not hungry or tired I just can't be bothered. So between my coach being on my case all the time :) and now the BC, I'm eating a lot more. I'm finding milk is about the only thing that tastes right to drink, so drinking that in the evenings. By then I'm fed up with how my tea tastes. Stopped HRT before DX, so the extra calcium is probably good. Used to have an alcohol problem a few years ago, but hardly drink these days. A whiskey occasionally, mulled wine is good Finding I have more of a sweet tooth these days. I read that the filgrastim affects blood sugar, maybe that's why. I do think physical activity is the biggie. Hubby's grandad died of old age in his nineties, smoked, drank, strong black coffee red meat etc all his life. But he worked hard outdoors all his life. As one friend put it - a healthy lifestyle is merely the slowest possible way to die. And even that doesn't seem to be true anymore. I drive 25 000 miles a year. Statistically I'm more likely to die in a road accident than from this cancer. So, all in balance. We still need to enjoy life!!

Posts.Title: CT vs Bone Scan

Posts.Content: Ok, let's see if I can get this right. The contrast CT is looking for things in the lymphatic system. Or, at a slightly different frequency of scan, can also be used to look for blood clots in the blood vessels. It is not used to look for cancer in the bones usually - the contrast is taken up in the fluid transport systems in the body. The MRI I'm not that familiar with, but I think it's similar. There's also the PET scan. I think these can see things in the bones, on the right settings. I think they can also see stuff in the tissues. The nuclear bone scan will find any damaged areas in the bones. Mine caused a sharp intake of breath when it got to my knees - a 30 year old sports injury!! The nuclear stuff is taken into the bones, but takes longer - hence the 3 hour wait before the scan. I'm sure Dreamthief will be along at some point to clarify if I've missed anything. Hope that helps xx

Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Caravan28  I noticed you hadn't had a reply yet. Unfortunately the pathology does sometimes change after surgery, once they have got the whole thing under the microscope so to speak. However it's not the norm. Try not to cross any bridges you haven't got to yet!! The waiting is hard, so try to stay busy. Well, as busy as you can after the surgery! How are you doing with the exercises? Please make sure you keep up with them, so that you get mobility back. You will need that for radiotherapy. You've had the mx, and I assume the lymph nodes checked as well. So the cancer is gone. All that's left is to mop up the strays. As you are HER2++ you will have to have chemo so that you can get Herceptin, which is a biological therapy that targets the HER2 cells. The prognosis for HER2+ has improved enormously since Herceptin became available, so please don't listen to Dr Google as he is out of date. Also you will have Tamoxifen (or AI's if you are post menopause). As you are ER8, they will be of massive benefit to you. You've got this!! One day at a time. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Peripheral neuropathy joint pains and letrozole

Posts.Content: Everyone is different. Mine didn't start coming out till after the 2nd cycle. Not in clumps, but pretty steady. Hubby cut it to No4 at that stage as I was dropping hair all over my customer's houses - not a good look :) . It kept dropping so eventually just used the clipper without a comb, so about 2mm long. I'm now a week past 4th cycle, still have quite a few tufts. Nose hair is gone, but still have everything else. I was sooooo looking forward to not shaving my legs for a few months....... no such luck!! I wear a beanie most of the time, except when a hot flush strikes, when it's strip off time.

Posts.Title: Coffee support groups

Posts.Content: The funniest moment I had was with the surgeon before my op. He had me standing with all on show while he measured my old boob in all directions. I then dressed and sat next to the nurse. Said surgeon was paging through all sorts of catalogues, going this way and that. I looked at the nurse and said "He can't find one small enough" (I'm 36AA). We were rolling around almost literally wetting ourselves. Surgeon looks up with a frown as if to say "what's so funny". As it happens, bionic boob is a bit big, but I've learned to live with it. And I'm getting tired of being told how well I look. I wish I felt it!! Good luck with your show!! xx
Posts.Title: My annual fund-raising stand-up routine - need more material !

Posts.Content: Sacha I had left mx and anc 2 months ago with immediate implant with mesh. It's fine. They will select the best shape to match what you had. I was shown all the options ahead of time. I have full movement and am pretty much doing everything I was doing, have done for a couple of weeks already. No heavy stuff until wound is completely healed (about 6 weeks), but kettles etc are fine. The most important bit - you can get a cuppa!! Keep up with the exercises, very important. 3 days is not long. It takes a few weeks for all the swelling to go. Keep on top of the pain relief - it's better than trying to catch up when the pain gets away from you. Good luck next week. xx
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: I have the mesh Sacha . It means the pectoral muscle is not disturbed too much, and left where it's supposed to be. Implants come in different shapes and sizes. Mine is a 220ml(I think!) teardrop. Shape wise it is pretty close, although it's bigger than I'd have liked (I'm AA cup) so that is taking a bit of getting used to. It still feels quite tight, but there is still some swelling and not finished rads yet. So it may settle to the right size yet. Doesn't bother me particularly though. Plus side, there is more there to hold my archery chest guard in place - I'm not having to constantly re-adjust it anymore!! Silver linings and all that!!
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Skbbaby It's when the implant is held in place with a mesh overlay, rather than being put under the pectoral muscle. More comfortable and less hassles later. Sorry to hear you Mum had trouble with implants. Perhaps the best starting point would be the BCN or surgeon to see what other options there are. xx

Posts.Title: It may not be as bad as you think!

Posts.Content: Hey ash7 Yay for NEDdie!!! I was on Atorvastatin for a while as a precautionary measure after having chemo-induced heart failure. Way my cardiologist put it - it can't do any harm, and yes, it does have an effect on preventing recurrence. 6.4 isn't actually that high, but it won't do any harm to get it down some. Mine generally hangs around 3 - 3.5. I opted to stop the drug due to having ongoing joint issues, which statins can be a culprit for. And I wanted off as many meds as possible!! Just Ramipril to go now...... fingers crossed!! Hugs xx

Posts.Title: First Session of FEC T

Posts.Content: Hi Laurajane779  Welcome to the community.  How is your Mum recovering from her surgery? Well, I hope. She needs to make sure she does the exercises they should have given her. Very important for regaining shoulder mobility.  Mine was HER2+, so I had to have chemo in order to get the targeted drug Herceptin, which your Mum won't need. She may still need chemo though, due to the node involvement. They make that decision based on how many nodes, which is why they are waiting for those results before giving a treatment plan. Her age may play a part in the decision too. She will definitely be given an aromatase inhibitor (AI) such as letrozole. For ER/PR positive BC this is the main defence for the future, and very effective. Chemo isn't pleasant. But it is doable. The drugs on offer for side effects are very good these days. Please remember that she has had the surgery. So the cancer is gone. Everything else is either to mop up stray cells or to prevent recurrence. Please keep us posted, and feel free to ask any questions you may have. Or just have a good rant if you need to.  Would your Mum be comfortable joining us here? And here's a big hug for a lovely daughter!! xx
Posts.Title: Cancer type?

Posts.Title: its back for the third time

Posts.Content: Hi Tigha Welcome to the community - not that any of us wanted to be here, but it's a good place to get support and, very importantly, hugs. Lots of them!! Ok, first - breathe!! Diet. If we avoided the stuff they say is bad we'd not eat anything. Or breathe for that matter!! There are as many opinions as there are people. The best advice I can give you is - eat varied and balanced. What is right for one isn't necessarily right for another. If I had a pound for everyone who told me to eat kale............... I hate the bl00dy stuff!! I lived on milk during chemo because it was the only liquid that tasted right. Dairy is less of a problem in this country anyway, as organic cows don't get given hormones. Soy is the same - it's plant oestrogens. My understanding is the plant ones are actually ok, but I stand to be corrected. You need to keep your immune system up. But more importantly, you need fuel to fight the disease. During treatment it's a matter of eating what you can when you can. You also need to try to avoid stress!! So if it's stressing you out, put it to one side, and eat what you normally do. Google can be quite evil at times, so try to stay on decent sites like this one. There is so much info out there, claims for "alternative" therapies and so on, and little of it has a foundation of solid research. They don't actually know what causes most types of cancer.  Be kind to yourself above all. It is tiring, so take whatever help is offered.  Oh, and hydration, hydration, hydration. Here's one of those hugs I mentioned. I'm sure some of the others will be along soon to offer more!! xx

Posts.Title: Mucositis

Posts.Content: We're all different Joanne. I had full mobility in 10 days, and was back at work after 13 days. I needed the pain relief for about a week or so, then tapered it off. The most important things. Firstly, do the exercises. Up to shoulder height until the drain is out, then all of them. And keep doing them. My mx/fnc was in March, and I still stiffen up if I don't stretch. Be kind to yourself. It's a longer anaesthetic, and you will likely feel pretty crap for a couple of weeks.  It takes about 6 weeks for all the internal stitching to heal. After that, try to get back to what you were doing as quickly as you are comfortable doing it. Your arm and shoulder are used to certain things. They need to be allowed to continue to do those things. For me, it was installing burglar alarms and shooting arrows. My physio cleared me to start working up to 6-8kg weights after 6 weeks. Your upper inner arm will feel like you're rubbing sandpaper on it for up to 12 weeks. It will be numb for longer. Mine is ok now, but armpit still numb and likely to stay that way. The nerves sorting themselves out is like shooting pains. They come and go, and diminish over time. I rarely get them now. If they don't give you a bag for the drain, then sort out a shoulder bag let down to waist height. To carry the drain in. It won't come out if you forget and drag it behind you, but it hurts!! I went out and about with the drains, and even drove myself to the hospital to get the second one out. 10 days after surgery. Some ladies used a v-shaped pillow to rest the arm on for sleeping. I just lay on the other side with my arm over a pillow. My usual sleeping position. You've got this. And if you do struggle with pain, don't keep quiet. She who shouts loudest gets the best pain relief!! Hug? xx
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: There's not a lot to be done about them AkelaJean , unfortunately. Drives me completely bonkers sometimes!! Antidepressants sometimes help, strangely enough. Venlafaxine seems to be the one, from what I've seen on here. My GP wouldn't change mine to that, he said no one uses those anymore - which is not true, obviously. Whether my Mirtazapine has helped any is debatable, but I'm not coming off them to find out!! Lady magnet has worked for some - sticks on your underwear I believe. Then there's the herbal route. Evening primrose oil etc. As you are ER+, do be careful as some of these supplements have oestrogen in them. I'm in my second menopause now, after being on HRT for 10 years. No oestrogen killers for me though as I was ER neg. So HRT wasn't to blame. It's annoying, especially at night as you say, but I've got used to it for the most part. I dread summer though.... Hugs xx

Posts.Content: Hi Millie2018  Welcome to the community!!  What you are feeling is quite normal. Yes, even the anger!! It's totally not vain to worry about how it will look either. Posts.Title: Annoyed!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hey Croz - so sorry about your mum's diagnosis. You really have been having a tough time, both of you. That said, you've come to the right place!! And your mum sounds amazing!! It sounds like she will be getting Paclitaxel chemo which is the weekly Taxane. Most of us had the 3-weekly one Docetaxol. The weekly one is easier on the system as it's a much lower dose. That said, she will be tired, and probably have some pretty achy joints and muscles. As to her other condition, that is one for the medical staff. If I'm not mistaken, she will likely have low iron and VitB12 because of it, so those will need to be monitored on her pre-chemo bloods each week. Would your mum consider joining in here?  You could also look at the July Chemo Club, there are a lot of tips and tricks there which may be helpful. And also folks at around the same stage of treatment. She could also contact the MacMillan helpline, where there are a lot of really good people to talk to about stuff. They can help with all kinds of things, not just someone to talk to. Things like financial support and so on. 0808 808 00 00 Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm. Lastly, you need support too. Please feel free to talk on here when you need to, ask questions, or just vent!! Hugs xx

Posts.Title: how long did it take for your hair to fall out on EC?

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl34  And breathe!! What was the LVEF % do you know? They will most likely put you on heart meds - ACE inhibitors and/or beta blockers. If you are not yet below 50%, your Herceptin will continue. If it is too low, they will give the heart meds a couple of months to do their thing, and then restart Herceptin. Have you had 4 or 6 to date? I only had 12 Herceptin. I will not be getting any more, as I ended up with chemo induced heart failure. The heart meds as above together with statins and aspirin have improved my heart function, but I decided not to restart H. There is good evidence that 9 is actually sufficient. Please try not to panic. The heart meds are good, and they work. And the damage from Herceptin is reversible, so they will balance it out for you. Hug? xx

Posts.Title: July 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Hi DnA  Waiting is just the pits isn't it? Try to do stuff that doesn't involve cancer. I know the weather is rubbish at the moment, but perhaps a shopping trip? Buy silly stuff, useful stuff, try to have a bit of a laugh. Do NORMAL stuff. She will be a little quiet, it takes time for everything to sink in. But try to treat her the same as usual - we like to have a bit of normality in our lives. Time enough for the crap later. PLEASE stay away from Dr Google - he is very out of date and sometimes (as you've discovered) just plain evil. Stick to recognised sites like this one, CRUK and so on. And avoid American sites as they tend to be quite negative. BC treatment has moved on, and success rates are very high these days. They do a lot of tests and scans up front. This is so they have a very good picture and can set up a treatment plan that is quite personalised. So please try not to worry too much about that side of things. Grade 2 is intermediate aggressiveness, so it won't be growing very quickly. ER8 is good, very responsive to hormone blocker treatments. Spring clean the house so there's less to do during treatment? It helps to keep busy. Massive hugs to both of you xx
Posts.Title: Helping with waiting

Posts.Content: Hey Linkj  Definitely NOT a wimp!! Posts.Title: You must be nearly better now!!! What a whimp!

Posts.Content: Hey Kim1983  Okay, first thing to do is..... breathe. Now, it's stage 1, so you've caught it very early. Hats off to you for being observant - many of us weren't. Second, once you've had the surgery, the grade is not that important. And chemo will mop up any strays, wherever they might lurk. I won't lie and say it's easy. But it is doable. And you will do it, and get through the other side, for those youngsters of yours!! Please remember that breast cancer is very treatable these days. Survival rates are well over 90%, and higher when caught early as yours was. You have a couple of weeks of waiting now before surgery. Please do a couple of things. Firstly, stay away from Dr Google - he is very out of date. and sometimes just evil. So ask any questions here, or sites like CRUK. Secondly, get out and do fun stuff with the kids - it will keep you busy and keep your mind off this to some extent. Also, cook and freeze meals, so you don't have to worry about that after surgery. Cross this bridge first, don't think too far ahead, and take one day at a time. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hi chairleg123  - interesting choice of name? OK, so the easy bit - POSNOC trial - the link goes to the trial website. Now the hard bit. As you have had a positive lymph node, they will not do the OncotypeDX test. Which finds out how responsive your cancer would be to chemo. It might be worth asking about it though. Some folks here have paid to have it privately. Without the test, they would want to throw everything at it. Which is where the POSNOC trial comes in. Because you would be very closely monitored, they can be a little more conservative in the treatment. ER8/PR8 will be very responsive to endocrine therapy (tamoxifen et al), and that will be your best defence against reoccurrence. I had a 10mm tumour in 1 node, had full clearance and the others were all clear. But there was no way to know that without taking them out. Mine was Grade 3, very aggressive, so throwing everything at it was the only option. I don't envy you the decision. But go back to your team and ask as many questions as you need to. And please keep posting here - if nothing else it gets the jumble of stuff out of your head and into some sort of order. Besides, there's plenty of hugs available if you stick around!!

Posts.Title: Headache / dizzy & radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Cheekicow - interesting name!! First, welcome to the club none of us wanted to join. We are a pretty friendly bunch in here, and there is usually someone around to answer questions or lend a shoulder and give you a hug. Your family's reaction is not unusual, it is hard to come to terms with a cancer diagnosis and often people will almost ignore it in the hope it's not real. They will each come to terms with it in their own way and time. Not that that makes it any easier for you!! My office manager was a bit like that, even having had BC herself!! Can you talk with them about it? My hubby unfortunately really struggled with it, and fell apart more than once. I think I spent more time holding everyone else together than anything else. Is your husband coming to appointments with you? It is a good idea to have someone else there, as a lot of what they tell you will get lost in the fog. Another pair of ears (even a notepad!) is helpful to make sure you get everything. The waiting is the worst. Try not to worry too much (although you will - but try to contain it some), and keep busy while you wait for all the tests. And please do come back, so we can support you whatever happens. Breast cancer is very treatable these days, and the vast majority of women go on to live many good years! And you probably need a really big hug!! xx

Posts.Content: It's quite ok chairleg123 - there's an awful lot of information to take in very quickly!! I know I just went with the flow, and didn't really ask anything until after starting chemo!! I had that first due to it being aggressive. Most trusts don't do the test if there are positive nodes, it's just straight to chemo, don't pass go, don't collect £200!! There is the NHS Predict tool which might help a bit. It will give an idea of the % benefit of chemo. Ask your consultant about it, as he will have all your test results to hand. Push them for some estimates of the benefit of chemo. Anything over 5% benefit at 5 years, and it's probably a no brainer. Now, chemo is a scary thing. But it is doable. Not pleasant, but not everyone has an awful time either. I worked full time throughout. I'm sure others will be along who know more about the hormone positive side of things than I do. Hugs xx

Posts.Content: I find cocodomol does very little for me, and tramadol has no effect at all. I had (perhaps still have, they never did get to the bottom of it) some type of joint inflammatory problem that was causing excruciating pain. The rheumatologist I was seeing prescribed something called Arcoxia. Starting on 90mg a day and reducing to 60mg maintenance dose. It worked a treat, with no side effects. I have no idea what the active ingredient is. I'm suffering some again with chemo and Herceptin, nowhere near as bad, but it's exhausting. Onco unit wouldn't prescribe it, said I had to ask the GP, which I've not done yet. Might be worth exploring? Especially as the tramadol/cocodomol is something you get accustomed to and need more of for the same result. Much like any drugs of that type. PS Constipation - have you tried (if you can) very large doses of Vit C? Increase the dose till you get diarohea, then reduce it slightly. 8000mg a day for me when on steroids.
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Hi ks1966  Hmm, not uncommon unfortunately. The immune system takes a long time to sort itself out again after chemo. A flu shot is a good idea, as already suggested. But that will only protect against the strains it's made for, which is a best guess 6 months before flu season. And then there's all sorts of other respiratory viruses. She should get a full range of blood tests done, as there's a good chance something is lacking having not bounced back properly. And then whatever you can think of that would boost the immune system. But do consult with a GP first to make sure there's no contra-indications with any endocrine therapy etc. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: At last a result

Posts.Content: Hi Jo666 yes, T is known for the joint aches between days 4 and 10. The filgrastim injections also cause pain in the large bones due to the marrow being stimulated. Herceptin may also be partly responsible for some of your side effects. Have you tried Loratadine (Clarityn)? For some reason in seems to work for some on the filgrastim pain. You could also take ibuprofen in between the cocodamol so you have something every two hours. Not forgetting to check your temperature first of course. As you are HER2+, they do prefer you finish the T part of the chemo, as it is required by NICE in order to have Herceptin. BUT, NICE guidelines are just that - guidelines. It may be worth having a chat with your team, see what options you have. There are a few ladies here who were on the weekly paclitaxel, which should be 12, who only did 8 or 9. Which would be the same as dropping the last T.  I had the T spread over 4 cycles rather than 3. Good luck, whatever you decide to do - it is always your choice!!

Posts.Content: Hiya The steroids (and the crash!) are pretty awful. Where chemo is concerned they are used primarily in case of allergic reaction to the chemo, and a secondary benefit is anti-sickness. EC isn't too bad in terms of causing allergic reaction, but Docetaxol/Paclitaxel quite often have that effect and the steroid dose used is double that used on EC. Hence the "Tax Truck" when you come down off them!! Filgrastim is a bone marrow booster which gets the blood cell production kickstarted after each chemo dose, to try and avoid neutropenia. They aren't cheap, but they are far cheaper than a hospital stay for sepsis. It doesn't replace the steroids. It is possible to have the T part without steroids, but ANY sign of allergic reaction and it will be stopped immediately. There are other things they can do, like IV antihistamines and so on. Always worth asking beforehand about these. Hope that helps. xx

Posts.Title: just chatting

Posts.Content: Hi hugle32  Firstly, a warm welcome to the community. What a wonderful daughter you are!! How is your Mum doing after her surgery? Chemo. Ok, first thing, have a look at the May Chemo Club - the first post has a link to a useful hints and tips page. The main things to do before chemo - spring clean the house so that minimal cleaning is required for a while. And stock the freezer with tasty meals. Although bear in mind that taste buds are one of the things affected, so those meals may only be used in week 3 of each cycle. Stock up on a variety of drinks. Things don't taste right, and fluid intake is super important. I lived on tomato soup, milk and ice cream. Tea and coffee tasted awful - and I don't function well without a cuppa!!! So different flavours and textures. She will find the one that works.  Is she going to try the cold cap? If not, then a short haircut to minimise the trauma of hair falling out. I had hubby buzz cut mine - I'd always said that's what I'd do, so the commando look wasn't too much of an issue for me. Also, spend some fun time at the shops getting scarves and hats, or indeed wigs if that is her preference. The important thing is, have fun doing it, to take control of what is happening. Now, do YOU have a support network? I think we forget sometimes that those around us are suffering more in some ways, as you have no control over what is happening. And there is the fear of losing someone you love lurking in the background. There is an excellent Family and Friends group on this site, so why not pop over there too and see whether it may be of help to you. Please stay away from Dr Google through this, as he is often out of date and sometimes just plain evil. Stick to recognised sites like this one, CRUK and so on. Breast cancer is very survivable these days, with over 90% of women going on to live full lives. Last but not least, massive hugs to both of you!!! Please keep posting, and let us know how you are both getting on.
Posts.Title: preparing my mum for chemo

Posts.Content: Quite a few of us are on it Christmas71 . They have to tell you all the side effects, same as with chemo. But the ones you mention are fairly rare. Do see your dentist before you start though, as any work that invades your gums will need to be done first.  The ZA makes your bones deposit more calcium, so they become denser. This can sometimes lead to small fractures, but usually when the ZA is given for extended periods rather than the 3 year period we get it for. The first infusion may cause you to feel like you have the flu for a few days, but after that it's fine. Hugs xx

Posts.Content: Hey Lin Linkj  Yeah, mine went pretty low, but picked up quite quickly once chemo was done. I did have surgery after chemo, about 6 weeks if memory serves me right, and the pre-op bloods were fine. It's not a problem if RT starts in 6 weeks rather than 4 I shouldn't think. It is pretty much the mop up stage just in case. You could try eating liver (I like it, but I know a lot of folks don't!), as that is one of the iron rich parts of the beast. But really, it's about your marrow making new blood cells - red ones as well as white ones. And it does take some time. My bloods were worse a month ago that they were at pre-op in March. Will be having them checked again soon. Hugs xx
Posts.Title: Waiting for emotions to catch up with brain!

And don't try to cross bridges you haven't got to yet - you might never have to!!! I drive 25000 miles a year - statistically some plonker who bought their licence at the corner shop is going to get me eventually, not cancer. Or I could fall off a ladder. xx

Posts.Title: Macmillan Toilet Card

Posts.Content: Hi Mdeb01 , sorry you have found yourself here. But it is a good place to get support and advice. We're a pretty friendly bunch (if a bit bonkers!) and there is usually someone around to listen. Chemo isn't much fun, but it is doable. Although some days are one minute at a time. There are good meds for the sickness (if you get it, I didn't), and all the other possible side effects. Bear in mind that they have to tell you all of them to get consent, but very few get them all. The worst for me was fatigue and joint/bone pain.  Do you know what type of cancer you had? I say had, because you've had surgery so it's been removed. The chemo is to mop up any strays. And which chemo are you having? You might want to have a look at the monthly chemo club - August is here - the first post has a link to a blog with tips and advice. You will also find others at about the same stage of treatment. Are you trying the cold cap? There are a number of folk here who had some success in avoiding hair loss with it. You're not alone - we all walk with you every step of the way. And I'm sure you could use a big hug or two!! xx

Posts.Title: Nose sores!!

Posts.Content: Hi sunriser52  I had HER2+, and lymph node involvement. I was too soon for the P part, so I had 3xEC, 4xT and Herceptin. The tumour was 4cm at dx, and just over 2cm after surgery. The lymph was 1/15, and that was 1cm. After chemo. I had CT and bone scan prior to chemo, nothing since. It is not standard practice to do MRI etc after treatment unless there are symptoms that warrant it. My pathology showed clear margins, followed by RT. If all that didn't kill everything, too bad. I'm not well enough for more treatment at the moment. I have had to stop Herceptin after 12 due to heart failure. No hormonal treatment for me as ER0/PR0. I am getting biophosphonates. I guess if you push hard enough they will do a scan to "make you stop". But it is not standard practice. Re node involvement. One node was 10mm, and no trace in any of the others. So I am convinced the treatment worked. Hope that helps xx

Posts.Title: Docetaxol and Clexane

Posts.Content: Hi Elsie123  Are they not giving you Filgrastim (or similar) injections to do at home after your chemo? These are to help your bone marrow make new blood cells. Most centres give these now, although they are expensive they are a lot cheaper than hospitalisation for neutropenia. It's worth an ask I think. Do ask for the strongest they can give you on the painkiller side. The T part does cause joint and muscle aches, and it's a good idea to preload the painkillers. Take them before the pain builds up as it's easier to keep on top of that way. Hugs xx

Posts.Content: Hi Amo2017 - it does take a while to sink in doesn't it? Well done for getting through treatment!! It's a pretty intense time, and takes a while to get over. Have you got some nice stuff planned to do? Your risk profile for new primary on the other side won't change. As for recurrence, it's hard for anyone to say. I take it you had no node involvement? The grade, once the cancer is removed, is somewhat irrelevant. It refers to how different the cancer cells are to normal ones - but they have been removed. The radiotherapy was to mop up possible strays. Are you getting Tamoxifen or AI's? Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Docetaxol and Clexane

Posts.Content: I've just signed up for online repeat prescriptions. Which means I can also see all the letters on my file. And I found one there that I never saw at diagnosis time (I'm copied in on them usually) If I'm reading it right, my initial dx was TNBC from the core biopsy of the lump. I never saw that one. The HER2+ low amplification appears to have come from the fine needle aspiration of the lymph node. Which explains why my surgeon said I was HER2 neg. - leading to me having a meltdown over Herceptin. Made me wonder what else has gone on. So I've spent a half hour reading all the letters. The oncology registrar reported my LVEF as 55% (when the previous echo had been 54%), the oncologist said 50% but agreed to refer the scans to cardiology. SHE said - oh dear - you guys have overestimated this, it's actually 40% - stop Herceptin now. It looks like Oncology was trying to gloss things over to get me to continue Herceptin. I'm so glad I threw the toys out and refused!! So ladies, if you have the option of signing up for online repeats, do it. And read everything. And question anything that doesn't add up!! xx

Posts.Title: Zoledronic Acid

Posts.Content: Bursitis is horrible Karen1972. I get it from time to time, and at it's worst I can barely walk and can't lie on that side. It's too painful. I have had anaesthetic patches in the past, which are quite helpful. Usually it does resolve, but if not, and all non-invasive options are exhausted, they can drain the bursa to make things more comfortable. It is a last resort due to infection risk though. Heels are a no-no. They cause your ligaments and tendons to rub over the bones at the joints in ways they weren't designed to do. Which inflames the bursa more. Rest is the best thing to do. You could also try alternating heat with ice, it's more effective that way. Hugs xx
Posts.Title: Anastrozole hip pain, diagnosed with bursitis

Posts.Content: Yep. They're about the same size as those hot patches you can get. Need a prescription. xx
Posts.Title: Anastrozole hip pain, diagnosed with bursitis

Posts.Content: Unfortunately most of the herbal/vitamin remedies are oestrogen based, so you shouldn't have them. It sounds like the sleep deprivation is the worst part - it certainly is for me. There are things you can do for this. The usual route is certain antidepressants reduce hot flushes significantly, which will help your sleep. They will help with the mood swings to a degree also. Most of the other symptoms DO ease with time. How much time? We're all different unfortunately, so it's hard to say. There are some ladies on here who are taking antidepressants for this, so they would be able to advise which ones. I'll do a bit of poking around and see if I can find out. Paracetamol regularly can help with the painful symptoms. I always found a hot bath helps with the joint issues. Increase water intake - strangely that can help with bloating. Keeping active is hard, but it also helps. I had to stretch and mobilise joints before getting out of bed, especially ankles/Achilles, or I'd fall over when I stood up. Hope that helps. Will be back shortly if I find anything out xx

Posts.Title: Numb nostril

Posts.Content: Oh, I think the benefits far outweigh a couple of fluey days twice a year!! Only had one so far, next one in a couple of weeks, when I've had the bloods done. Others have assured me the first is the worst. I started menopause at 39, so had been on HRT for 10years when I found the lump. (I'm hormone negative, so HRT not to blame!) The risk of osteoporosis was too high not to. And I had every symptom in the book, it was awful. Moody cow, check. Alternating between freezing and dripping, check. Exhaustion and lack of sleep, check. Achy bones and joints, check. Constipated chicken walk, check. Getting chucked into it for the second time was the least fun bit of this whole palaver. I'm only just 50, GP won't let me back on HRT, so Zoledronic Acid is the way to go. It's only for 3 years.  Nothing noticeable, although I'm sure they would see it on xrays and stuff. It has the added benefit of helping to prevent bone secondaries. xx

Posts.Content: Cocodamol is codeine phosphate and paracetamol. I took the OTC ones most of the way through chemo, but am on prescription ones now. Ibuprofen, Naproxen, Aspirin, Arcoxia etc have to be stopped at least a week before any surgery, or the blood won't clot!! xx

Posts.Content: Hey ladies Not sure Herceptin accounts for all of it. I had my last H back in July (stopped after 12), and totally stiffen up within 10min of sitting now. I suspect it is down to lack of oestrogen, as I had the same when I started menopause 12 years ago. It went on HRT which my GP stopped, and has pretty much been a constant since end of chemo. So I do the constipated chicken walk, and drop things regularly because my finger joints are sore. Very painful some days, and have a repeat script for 30mg cocodamol. That only gives me an hour or so when I take 2. It's tricky when I'm driving an hour or two at a time, and have to stop and walk frequently.  Movement is about the only thing that helps, apart from hot baths. I'm not on any AI's or Tamoxifen by the way. I've about had enough, and am thinking about going back on HRT. xx

Posts.Content: Hi Lyndyloo60  Firstly may I say Wow!! Your weight training is impressive!! PICC line. It is unlikely you will be able to continue at those weight levels. The main problem is the line slowly pulling out of the vein. It can't be pushed back in due to infection risk. See if you can get a Portacath. I wasn't going to be able to shoot arrows with a PICC, so they gave me the Portacath. It is all internal, fitted under local. Needs about a week to heal and settle. Then you can do most things - I did archery and continued to install intruder alarms. If you push the quality of life and mental wellbeing angle hard, they should help you out. Wellbeing is incredibly important during chemo, and make a huge difference to how we cope with it. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi jacks77  That kind of makes sense. As the ZA will make the bones stronger and more dense. But you may want to start pushing for a DEXA scan about a year before the ZA finishes, as waiting times are looooong. I'm getting ZA for 3 years too, had 2 and 4 to go. I asked if I needed a DEXA, and my oncologist said no, he didn't want the waters muddied. He wanted me to have the ZA as a reoccurrence prevention, and if the DEXA results were good then I wouldn't be allowed to have it.  I was on HRT for 10 years prior to dx, and have been back on it for a week now. I couldn't cope with the pains and lack of sleep. Mine was hormone negative, and onco okayed it. xx
Posts.Title: DEXA Scan

Posts.Content: Yes jacks77 , it makes the bones denser. Bone mets tend to take hold in the spaces in the bones, so if they are more dense then it can't get a hold. Other bifossys are used to keep bone mets stable I think. I only started after chemo, it wasn't mentioned so I asked about it, and my onco jumped on it and said yes of course I need to have them!! I think the CCG's pay for it, so it is a bit of a lottery. xx
Posts.Title: DEXA Scan

Posts.Content: I had a permanent silicone implant (immediate reconstruction) and had no issues with it from RT. It's not the implant that is affected normally - it's the surrounding tissue and muscle contracting which causes capsulation. My surgeon was adamant there wouldn't be a problem, but I wasn't convinced at the time.... xx

Posts.Content: I would go for the port every time. I had the first 2 chemos by cannula, which was ok, but the veins are still a bit hard months later. Posts.Title: How are you?

Posts.Content: We are indeed all different Sacha !! My hair did start growing on T. Had a good covering of fluff by the end of chemo. I ached everywhere I'd ever had an injury. All sports injuries and there were a few. 15mg cocodamol was sufficient though. Chemo Wed, worked Thur/Fri, crash started Fri night. Was back at work Mon. The crash is harder because the steroid dose is higher. Steroids make you hungry. I gained weight because I ate whatever tasted ok. Probably 1 1/2 stone over the 4 months of chemo. But I was 1st underweight at the start. For me it was easier than EC. Because I didn't feel totally rubbish for 10 days every cycle. The effects are cumulative. The last of 4 was the worst, and I took a couple of extra days off. Hope that helps!! Hugs xx

Posts.Title: After radiitheraphy

Posts.Content: I had a call from one of the techy people today. Good news is, they appreciate the importance of the online community. And they have a new version in the works that will hopefully fix stuff. Bad news is, he couldn't give me a timeframe, and said it isn't an easy fix either. He said that ANY information on specifics - phone/pc/laptop, operating system, browser - is helpful in trying to pinpoint the bugs. So please continue to send in forms, with as much detail as you can. xx
Posts.Title: Technical issues - how to report.

Posts.Content: That wasn't what he was saying mistymoley. I think they are struggling to understand what the problem actually is. So by gathering info on how the issue presents with different platforms and browsers, it helps them to work out what is actually happening.  It seems to me that there is  a plug-in issue, which is affecting different combinations in different ways. And I think THAT has been an issue for quite some time. The Azure crash and the last Windows10 update have created the perfect storm, and they just can't work out where the coding translation has broken. I agree, it would make sense to go back to the hard server, the last point where things actually worked. But to make that work properly, all dormant accounts and old threads should also be archived, to improve traffic flow. I certainly didn't get the impression they are blaming US, in any way. Quite the opposite actually. I'm aware of a number of websites, hubby's work training platform is one, that just will not work with certain browsers. Now that isn't a problem for them, as they can use work PC's to do their training if necessary. For us, completely different story -  My phone came up with a switchboard number. I think his name was Matthew, but I can't swear to it. I was so taken aback getting the call when I had specified email contact only, that I didn't take it in.
Posts.Title: Technical issues - how to report.

Posts.Content: I was that bad after 2nd cycle. Chemo unit said to get it checked out at A&E. Turned out to be nothing, but they said I was right to come in. 20 paces is not good, so you should probably ring the chemo line and/or go to A&E. Hope you get it sorted xx
Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: Hi Baduki1 Firstly, well done getting through surgery!! I hope you are managing the exercises and getting your shoulder movement back. OK, so you had a sentinel node biopsy. They inject dye to trace the lymph drainage from the breast, and the first 3 or so show up brighter than the rest, so they are the first in line. Most often, the spread stops there. Now comes the tough decision for you. It could have spread to further nodes. But if the scan shows it clear, then it's a few cells and not an actual growth. There are 2 ways of dealing with it. Radiotherapy to the armpit to zap any cells that may have escaped. OR, a full axillary node clearance. Both carry risks and advantages, which you will need to discuss with your oncologist. Just to take some of the worry away, I had a node show up very hot on ultrasound. So a full clearance was always the plan for me. I had 15 nodes, and only that one was positive. It was still a 10mm tumour after chemo, and had not spread any further. There are others here who had 30 or more nodes, with most of them positive, and they are still here and still NED. So, I guess you have a lot of questions for your team. Don't be afraid to ask them, and keep asking until the answers make sense!! Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: I wasn't actually given much of a choice Baduki1. I didn't want RT and ended up going with that too. But, mine was Grade 3, HER2+ so it wasn't something I was going to take any chances with. My surgeon wanted to try a lumpectomy as he felt chemo had shrunk it enough. I insisted on mx, I wanted it gone. And being AA cup, and still had over 2cm lump, there wasn't going to be much left!! He wouldn't entertain anything less than full clearance though, and he was right. And I've not had any issues either, 18 months on now. I had RT to the collarbone and chest wall. The lump was 4cm to start with, so me being quite small, it was close to the chest wall and ribs. I did want to keep RT in reserve for the future. Because if it comes back on that side, I can't have RT again. All that said, I'm happy with what I had done. And with the results. Just as an idea of what is possible - I achieved a Master Bowman classification in archery a couple of weeks ago. After shooting over 300 arrows in 2 days. So the clearance hasn't caused me any issues. Good luck with your decision, and don't make it until you are happy with the choice. Hugs xx

I couldn't find a wedding dress I liked, so looked at patterns and didn't like them either. Ended up designing and making my own. It was an engineering project as that's how my brain works!!

The ladies on there might be able to give you more information. The best place to get a proper diagnosis and so on - yes, you know the answer - your consultant. It's only a few more days till you get your results, so hang in there honey. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: New here and supporting my sister with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Emmies  The waiting for tests, and waiting for results, is probably the worst bit really isn't it? OK, further tests. They usually do a contrast CT of the upper body lymph system, and a nuclear bone scan. Please try not to worry too much. Mine was 4cm x 3m Grade 3 when I found it, and already spread to lymph node - they could see it on the ultrasound. The extra scans showed no further spread. I had probably had it for at least 8 months already by then. I had chemo first due to being HER2+, then surgery. The post surgery pathology showed no further lymph nodes were affected, just the one. They will want to make sure they have got it right before starting treatment, to make sure your mum gets the right treatment for her. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Herceptin side effects help

Posts.Content: Hey Googieswife  My initial dx was TN. The pathology on the affected node came back low amp HER2. So a similar dx to yours. And also no immediate family history, and no BC or PC in extended family. (F)EC chemo (I didn't have F) reduced my lump by over half (40mm to start with!!), although I'm not convinced Tax did anything at all. But that's just me. I had mx, anc and RT after chemo. No further nodes were affected, so the chemo stopped any spread. I'm now a year out, and more or less back to normal. Well, about as normal as things get I suppose.  Hang in there. The chemo you're having works on TN. There's at least one person here who had PCR (complete response). And RT works to pick up any strays from any type of BC. Hugs xx
Posts.Title: Just found out all my results!

Posts.Content: Yes, the PICC is a semi-permanent line inserted into the vein in your upper arm, which goes inside the vein all the way to just above your heart. It means no needles for bloods or chemo, and no damage to your veins. The drawback of PICC is it can't get wet, and you can't do things which involve stretching or overhead movements. That was never going to work for me - I install burglar alarms and do archery!! So they arranged for me to have a Portacath, which is completely internal and accessed through the skin each time. Hugs xx
Posts.Title: New chemo starter

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that tiger-777 . About the hospital. I was fortunate in that I had a choice of hospitals. Although both are pretty good. You don't have to have a line. But I think pretty much everyone will tell you to beg for one. I had one chemo in each arm, and the veins are still cr*p 6 months later. The port was a lifesaver!! They may try to tell you chemo doesn't damage veins. They will be lying. Having one inserted is pretty straight forward, and they use local anaesthetic so you don't feel anything. When I had the port fitted, we laughed from beginning to end!! Have a proper hug xx

Posts.Content: Hi Autumn16  Well done, getting to the end of chemo!! I guess you've had (F)EC-T? Lashes and brows can take a while, and they may come and go for a bit. Because they all grow back together and then most fall out again on their natural cycle. It evens out again eventually. You may have some fluffy hair regrowth already. Mine was pretty much back a couple of moths after chemo when I had it cut to about a no.5 to even it all out. Although I had a good covering by the end of chemo as it started growing again on the T part. The rest of my hair grew back first, I could have done without having to get a razor out again!! Hope that helps. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: IWe do have a great thing in the NHS, there are problems in some areas, but for the most part it works very well. I too have had all the conventional treatments. And am suffering extreme fatigue and joint pain as a result. But I will live. That said, there is a great deal of anecdotal evidence that more conservative treatments such as chloecat45 has had can contain the cancer and keep it stable for quite some time. Shrink it even. Which is helpful when it might be inoperable. We all want to give ourselves two things 1)the best chance of survival and 2)a reasonable quality of life. And these things need to be balanced to some degree. There is also significant research into many aspects of cancer treatment. Genome testing is used with great success in some areas. Like the OncotypeDX test, to determine whether chemo is of any benefit in ER+ cancer. Why have it if it isn't going to help? I'm having Herceptin. I am low amplification HER2+, and research shows it very likely isn't of any benefit to me at all. And now it's causing heart issues. I may very well choose to stop the treatment due to it causing more harm than benefit. Many of us do our own research. We look for and read papers being written about cutting edge treatment possibilities. And there are many. We don't think we know better than the scientists. But we do read as much as we can about the research that is happening. chloecat45 I wish you the very best in finding your way forward from where you are now. You've had a very difficult journey so far. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Enforced break in chemo worry

Posts.Content: Not a runner, but I was shooting arrows twice a week and working a physical job all the way through chemo. I needed to keep as much normality as possible to stay sane!! I had to stay home from the Indoor Nationals in Dec - it was 4 days after 1st Tax - and I just wasn't going to be able to do it. Only made the final decision the night before though..... I shot the Southern Counties Champs 3 1/2 weeks after my last chemo, came away with a medal. Back up to 6 1/2 dozen arrows again 2 1/2 months after mx & ANC, not strong enough for Surrey Outdoor champs this weekend, but on my way. Being out on the field in the sun shooting arrows again is brilliant, planning now for next season. Do as much as your body will allow, but no more. Remember you will be fatigued, you will have low blood counts. But keep moving!! Doing the things you love to do helps to keep motivated and keep going. xx

Posts.Title: Hair a fuzz ball

Posts.Content: I'm the same. I struggle to sleep at the best of times, but after a chemo cycle I'm lucky to get 2-3hrs at a time. Others who know more will confirm, but I think its the steroids that cause this. The chemo team can prescribe things to help. I prefer not to take anything, I can't stand the way I feel the next day. I tend to have a long hot soak before going to bed and find this helps. Also try to avoid being too warm in bed, the body needs a cooler temp to sleep. The worst of it does pass after about a week, but I suspect will never completely go back to normal.

Posts.Title: Advice with reconstruction: implants verus DIEP

Posts.Content: Statistics. Hmm. There's lies, damn lies and statistics..... :) I do agree there is some element of genetic disposition, same as for many other things. There are also a lot of other factors that never get mentioned, such as the GM component in what we eat. I'm sure there's GM stuff they never tell us about. There's the stress and pace of modern life - way too high imho. Diesel fumes - the aromatics in diesel are horrible. Strange chemicals and things in our workplaces - acetone, fumes released by plastics housing our computers etc. "Sick building" syndrome. So the statistics only tell us what percentage of people MIGHT get something based on historical information. But cause and effect? We'll probably never know.

Posts.Content: Hey ladies Staging takes account of the original tumour size as well as number of nodes. Also, it depends on whether the positive nodes were a few cells or actual tumours. Stage 3B to stage 4 are the ones to worry about. There isn't much difference between a high stage 2 and a 3A. Info here. Many trusts use the TMN staging these days, which is similar. Info here. I hope this helps. But please remember - once you have had surgery the cancer has been removed.  Hugs xx

Posts.Content: Yes, you will get Herceptin Scaredgirl34 . It seems likely, as you're having chemo first, that you will get Perjeta (Pertuzumab) as well. The combination has been giving excellent results. The type of chemo you have depends on other factors. So you may have 3x EC (or FEC), then 4x T (docetaxol). Posts.Title: ER status

Posts.Content: Hey Scaredgirl34 - please don't google HER2 - Herceptin hasn't been around long enough to have accurate survival data. Even the predict tool is not helpful as it doesn't allow for neoadjuvant chemo. And of course Pertuzumab there are no figures at all. It might be worth bothering them for an appointment on a cancelation. If you call every day or two, they might squeeze you in!! The waiting around is the worst part. I had a MUGA scan last week, no results yet. If I don't get them by Wed, I will be missing yet another Herceptin shot as I have refused to continue until I get an accurate LVEF measurement. Had my one year mammo on Thursday. More waiting for results. But once you actually get going it should help you settle down. Try to keep busy, and restrict the time you spend worrying. Use the time to prepare. Stock the freezer with precooked meals.  Spring clean the house - you won't get to it again for a year due to low energy levels. If you have offers of help, transport, chemo buddies - nail them down to firm arrangements. And get lots of hugs!! xx
Posts.Title: ER+ and HER2+

Posts.Content: Hey Sharmer , yes the wait is quite wearing. It is likely they will send you for a contrast CT scan, which is when those other lymph nodes will get checked. Along with all the others. Some trusts also do a bone scan prior to starting treatment as well. Mainly to get a baseline for you, but also just to check there is nothing else going on. Things like maybe only one kidney etc. So don't panic if they send you for more tests, it's fairly standard. Be kind to yourself during this week!! And remember that breast cancer is pretty treatable these days. xx

Posts.Title: What today was like.....

Posts.Content: Hey summerholiday  A very warm welcome to the community - the club none of us particularly wanted to join!! I didn't have any scans during chemo at all. In fact I didn't even see my oncologist, just his (pretty useless) registrar half way through. I thought it shrunk a lot on EC, but T had no effect at all. So a midway scan wouldn't have meant much anyway.  The usual wait for scan results would be 10-14 days, so try not to worry too much about it. I'm sure you have a good idea of whether it feels smaller or not - I know I couldn't stop poking the thing to see!! The other thing is, sometimes the tumour just goes soft as the cells die, rather than disappearing. So the scan is an indicator, rather than a definitive. The only definitive here is the post surgery pathology. Did you have any hot lymph nodes? That might be what they mean by satellite nodules, but I don't think so. I'm glad you have managed the side effects well - we need more "good" chemo stories, as those are the ones we don't hear about!! Do keep posting on here, and have a look at the April Chemo Club (if you haven't already!), as there is a lot of useful info there if you need it. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: Reconstruction with animal matrix and implants

Posts.Content: Unfortunately it did. My last scan showed some improvement though, so fingers crossed. Make sure they stay on top of getting your echo scans. Most people are absolutely fine though. The cardiologist thinks the C part of EC chemo is the main culprit, rather than Herceptin. But H didn't help any. Do report any shortness of breath or chest pains, and make sure they follow up on it. If I had got the heart meds sooner, some of the damage could have been avoided. BUT, and this is a BIG BUT, don't try to cross any bridges until you get to them. Because you may never get there!! Hugs xx

Posts.Title: YORK MEET-UP 9TH SEPTEMBER 2017

Posts.Content: Hi simba4me  Welcome to the club none of us want to be in. Firstly -you are NOT alone!! There is usually someone around here to listen, or a shoulder to cry on if you need to. You have a lot on your plate. Do you have any other support? If not, perhaps give the helpline a call, as they will be able to help with getting the support you need. 0808 808 00 00 Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm Do you know what surgery you are having? And any further treatment you will need? A bit more information will help us to support you better. Please remember that breast cancer is very treatable these days. The vast majority of women go on to live full lives. But it is a hard few months getting through the treatment, so be kind to yourself. Posts.Content: You will have to avoid anything that pushes oestrogen up, which knocks out most herbal remedies. I'm sure you will get more responses from those who have tried acupuncture and ladycare magnets with great success. Apparently caffeine makes it worse, so worth cutting that out to see. I've heard the same about carbs. Some anti-depressants are good at stopping/reducing hot flushes. That is the route I've taken, as I have started sliding back into depression. The one I've chosen is Mirtazapine, because I know from experience it has a good sedative effect. There are others, I'm sure someone will be along to share. Posts.Title: Scared, I think my breast cancer has gone to my liver....

Posts.Content: I can answer some of those I think - if my brain works!! EC is effectively the same as FEC. Some trusts no longer use F as the side effects outweigh the benefits. I had EC, and worked through it as I didn't get much in the way of side effects. My EC was accelerated so every 2 weeks, and I had 3 of them. Side effects - some nausea controlled with meds, and fatigue. One A&E visit for chest pains that turned out to be nothing, but had to be checked out. T there are 2 different ones. Paclitaxel (Taxol) is weekly for 12 weeks. The dosage is lower, and so the side effects hopefully not as severe. Docetaxal (Taxotere) is usually given every 3 weeks for 3 cycles. However, some have it accelerated, every 2 weeks (possibly at a slightly lower dose, I don't know). I had mine in 4 cycles for the same total dose, so mine were 75 whatevers, rather than the usual 100. Side effects - not straight away due to steroids. Days 3/4 - 7/9 bone and joint aches, again controlled with meds. Also acid reflux. Sorry you had to have ANC. I had mine 2 weeks ago after chemo. We knew from the original scans I had node involvement, so went straight to mx and ANC without SNB. I had immediate implant recon, and now back at work. (I work from home at the moment). Don't worry too much about the differences - we are all different, and most oncologists tailor the treatment to suit our specific set of pathology. In your case, the cancer is out, and the chemo is to mop up any stray cells left behind. It's scary, but it is doable. One minute at a time some days, but doable. Good luck xx

Posts.Content: Hi Emmie76 - Welcome to the friendliest group of crazy people around!! As LondonLass says, first take a deep breath and try to relax. Not easy, I know. The waiting for tests and results is indeed the hardest part. Most lumps are not sinister. I didn't see a surgeon until after the tests. I was referred on an urgent 2 week referral, and had mammogram, ultrasound and biopsies all at the same time. (breast lump and suspicious node) After that you will be called back for results. This can be 2 or 3 weeks after the scans, although they do try to get you in sooner some centres are very busy and it's not possible. It is probably a good idea to insist on a biopsy, even if the ultrasound doesn't show it as hot. For your peace of mind as much as anything else. Again, try not to worry too much. Although you will. This sounds like a very early catch, which is good. Worrying can't change the result, and if it should turn out to be cancer, you're on the conveyor which does move pretty quickly for the most part. Here's a link to what happens during this testing stage  Try to keep busy, rest when you can. And here's another hug, I'm sure you can use a few right now!! xx

Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi Acidomoduso there are no pointless questions here!! Sorry you find yourself here, especially as you are worried about your Mum. Although we are a friendly bunch and will help as much as we can. Ok, so to try to answer some of your questions. Grade refers to how aggressive the cancer is. So if the cells are not much different to normal ones it's grade 1. When the cancer cells are very well differentiated from normal ones, it's grade 3. That is not necessarily something to worry about. Mine was grade 3, due to being HER2+. Grading can change when the pathology is repeated after surgery as the sample is larger. A lot of centres don't give staging unless it's stage 4 (metastatic). Mine did't give me a staging. Although I had lymph node involvement. The staging depends on various factors, including size of tumour and node involvement.  You can find some more information on grading and staging here. The CT is usually to check the rest of the lymphatic system. I can't say why they might want another at this stage.  The bone scan is pretty standard these days. Most of us had one at some point. It does provide a baseline for reference in the future. Mine picked up some anomalies, which were old injuries. Please try not to worry too much (although you will, of course, it's your Mum!), but try to restrict the time you spend worrying. Do ask anything you need to know, or just vent your emotions, on here. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: New here

Posts.Content: Hi Debs GrandmaRob Also want to say how lucky your aunt is to have you!!  A question first - is she having a node clearance as well? That would make the recovery time a bit longer. I'm quite a bit younger, but was pretty much back to normal in a month after mx and node clearance. Things she will need help with : Cleaning, laundry, shopping. Anything that needs both arms and heavy (ish) lifting. Making tea and cooking and stuff like that is fine. As long as the kettle is not full (1/2 full is what I was told). If she still drives, she won't be able to for at least 2 weeks. Very important - there are exercises that need to be done. 3x a day. Every day. She may need encouragement to do them - I know I just can't be bothered sometimes, and I lose mobility very quickly! You can download those from the web, will look and see if I can find a link. Starting on those before surgery can be helpful. Arnica. tiny tablets from H&B, very helpful for the healing process. Drink plenty, hospitals can be very dehydrating. I hope all goes well for your aunt, please do let us know. And feel free to ask any questions you have - there's usually someone around who can help. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: 2nd biospy delayed by 3 months.

Posts.Content: Hi Ekshepherd , welcome to the club none of us wanted to join.  That has to have been hard, being diagnosed while pregnant!! It all moved pretty fast for you by the looks of it, I'm sure your head is still spinning!! I trust you have enough family support, having a newborn and a mastectomy can't be easy. The pain in your arm may well be completely unrelated, although often the body finds a way to warn you something isn't right. Until you get your pathology results (do you know yet when you're getting results?), it is impossible to advise really. A shooting pain seems more likely to be a nerve, and there will be added nerve pains after your surgery as they have been cut. Please try not to spend all your time worrying, although it can be hard not to. Once the post-surgery pathology is done, they will have a better idea of where you go next. You say it's hormone positive - that is a "good" thing, as you will get Tamoxifen which is VERY effective. Breast cancer is very treatable these days, with well over 90% survival. There's someone around on here most of the time, so feel free to ask any questions or just ramble/vent as you need. Plenty of ears and shoulders!! And I'm sure you can use a hug or two!! xx

Posts.Content: Yes Boobylou I'm getting it. You will need to have a blood test the week before to check you have enough calcium available. Side effects. The first 2 days were worse than chemo. I was proper laid out. But fine after that. Apparently the first one is the worst - will let you know in November when I get the 2nd...... You need to see your dentist. If there are any issues requiring extraction or other gum invasion, they need to be sorted out before starting ZA. Invasive dental work cannot happen once you start. Fillings and hygienist are fine. It is to increase bone density, not only to prevent osteoporosis, but also to protect against bone secondaries.  Hope that helps. Hugs xx

Posts.Content: Mine have been low for years. Way before my dx. My GP at the time said that over 70% of the population in UK had an "insufficiency", although a complete "deficiency" was less common. This due to the lower levels of exposure to sunlight. Although I spend hours on archery fields in the summer........ My current issue is, in spite of taking 4000iu D3 a day (with K2), my levels do not increase. Current GP doesn't believe me, so I will be requesting another test soon which he has already agreed to. I suspect that hypothyroidism has an effect on VitD absorption. And thyroid issues are rather common post cancer treatment. Although my thyroid issues go back further, but untreated due to "normal" (it was actually upper end of normal) TSH. RT killed half of my thyroid, so now I'm getting treatment. Will report back after the next round of tests.
