Posts.Content: Hi Sacha I had left mx with implant and full node clearance on 21 March. Drains out days 8 & 10. Driving after 2 weeks. It is very important to do the exercises to regain mobility, and keep doing them. My own physio gave me more to do which really helped. I suspect my archery played a big role in my recovery, as my left shoulder was in pretty good shape from that. I have a numb patch under my arm and halfway down to my elbow. My nipple was saved - a risk, as it may have meant further surgery, but it paid off as margins were clear. Funniest thing is, it itches - but I can't feel anything when I scratch it!! Some shooting pains where nerves are trying to sort themselves out. Doesn't look like there is any issue with the implant and radiotherapy - 10 of 15 done this morning. I'm probably not the person to ask about self-image type stuff. I'm honestly not bothered. But it was probably a good thing to wake up still having a boob, even if it is a bionic one!! Hope that helps a bit xx

Posts.Content: Please be careful with Dr Google mum and mia - stick to sites like this one or CRUK. There is a lot of outdated and wrong information out there!! Your chemo is likely to be one of 2 combinations, EC+T, with Herceptin starting alongside T (Epirubicin, Cyclophosphamide + Taxotere (Docetaxol)) TCH Taxotere, not sure what the C is here, not the same one, Herceptin. The Herceptin carries on by itself, some trusts do 17, mine does 18. Although I am refusing any more until they resolve the heart issue I've developed. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor, effectively an oestrogen killer. I don't get those as mine was ER0. Egg on my GP's face as HRT had nothing to do with my cancer..... You will have an echocardiogram before starting H, with follow ups around every 3 months. They are checking LVEF left ventricle ejection fraction. That needs to be over 55% to get H, and if it drops below 50% H has to stop until it recovers. Mine was estimated at my last echo, apparently they couldn't measure it because of my implant. It's borderline, which is why I've refused to continue. Hope all that helps. You pick it all up as you go along. You may want to have a look through the August Chemo Club thread. Do remember that those without bad side effects tend not to post, so don't take it too literally that that's how you will feel. We're all different. xx

Posts.Content: Hi Harridamen  Welcome to the community. The place none of us wanted to be, but where there are friendly ears and shoulders. And lighter moments too. It's ok to be frightened. Please be kind to yourself during the waiting for results bit (and after that too!!). It's the hardest part for a lot of people. Once you have results and a plan, it does get easier. I was hormone negative and HER2+, and node positive. The breast lump was 4cm, and the node was still 1cm after chemo. I had chemo, mastectomy + node clearance + implant, and radiotherapy. My Herceptin (for HER2+) was stopped after 12 of 18, as my heart wasn't coping. I am 1 year clear, and discharged by cardiology too. Won't pretend it was easy, but it is doable. I worked fulltime throughout. The nodes are there to catch the nasties. And it's a job they do very well. Please remember that breast cancer is very treatable these days, with well over 90% of women going on to live full lives. Stay away from Dr Google though - he is very out of date and sometimes just plain evil!! Wait until you have all the results, and then ask on here or other reputable sites. One thing that is ALWAYS available here is hugs. Lots of them!! So consider yourself hugged!! xx

Posts.Content: Hi Juju68 , welcome to our friendly community! It could be any or all of the above. Not what you wanted to hear, I know. I had early menopause at 38 (had a hysterectomy at 30), the joint aches, flushes and stiffness were awful. I was barely sleeping. As I was so young, I decided the risk of osteoporosis was too high not to go on HRT. Which I took for 10 years. Fast forward to 49th birthday and a cancer diagnosis. But ER0/PR0 so not connected to the HRT at all. HER2+, so had to have chemo. I stopped the HRT the day I found the lump, and was back in full menopause within 2 weeks - before even starting chemo. I finished chemo 8 Feb.  The aches, stiff joints, sweats and fatigue have got steadily worse. I'm not on Tamoxifen.  So, what to do. I'm taking Evening Primrose oil, Glucosamine, Vit D + K2, etc etc. Also on antidepressants Mirtazapine which has a mild sedative effect. And menopace multi vits. The sweats seem to have reduced a little, in number and intensity. That may be my body adjusting to the lack of oestrogen, it may be some of the above supplements. The joint aches and stiffness is getting worse. I have osteoarthritis in my hands, so it's unlikely to improve. On cocodamol 4x a day just to function. I wish I could tell you a miracle solution. We're all looking for one!! Fluoxetine - I think it's contra indicated with Tamoxifen anyway. Venlafaxine - there are a few folk on here who take it. The anecdotal evidence for it helping with flushes is quite strong. I also take Ambien (sleeping pills) 2 or 3 times a month to try and get the odd good night. Hot bath before bed helps. My alarm is set 1/2 hour before I need to get up, so I can get the joints moving in time to get out of bed. And lastly, a big gentle hug -I'm sure you could use one!! xx

Posts.Content: Hi Winney  Sorry to hear you've run into some issues. It's not uncommon for this to happen, and yes, it is reversible. I'm guessing you've been put on Ramipril, which makes a difference pretty quickly. Once LVEF has gone over 55% again, they will restart your Herceptin. Depending on how long that takes, you may need to have another loading dose. One question - was your HER2 +++ or low amplification? If the latter, then you might want to question whether it's even necessary to finish the H. I stopped after 12, and as it was low amp have elected not to continue. Cardiologist has discharged me as LVEF has been restored to normal. Hugs xx

Posts.Title: BC stage 3B - private treatment

Posts.Content: Hey Maisie17  I had Herceptin only (did 12/18 and stopped due to heart issues), but my HER2 was low amplification so it's debatable whether H was of any benefit to me at all. Research evidence backs this up, and onco agreed. However, there are a number of ladies on here (the first group who had TCHP), who had pathological complete response (PCR). It seems that this is the case in over half of patients. Perjeta/Pertuzumab is the latest gamechanger for HER2+ cancers. Going back to Herceptin. One of my customers was among the first to get Herceptin when it was initially approved. That was 12 years ago, and she is still NED. So any onco that poo poos the HP combo needs to be reported. The evidence is plain - it works. H alone has improved 5 year survival for HER2+++ from around 60-70% to 85% plus. P will improve that still more. Hugs xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hiya. I assume you've had EC or FEC so far? How was that for you? Tax - you will have steroids to take from the day before, so expect to not sleep. Plan to spring clean the kitchen cupboards or something, you have 3 days of that. Side effects don't really kick in until day 3/4, extreme fatigue, joint and bone pain. Get the painkillers in early and keep up with them to stay on top of it. Acid reflux rather than nausea - they can give you stuff for that just ask. Lasts to about day 7-9. Good after that. Furry mouth and cr*p taste. Use the mouthwash (and warm salt or bicarb solution before and after eating) Eat whatever tastes right, don't worry too much about what it is. Possibly diarrhoea rather than constipation. I stayed constipated, took 8000mg of Vit c a day to control it. Herceptin - may cause a bruise if they inject too quickly or you tense up. Relax, they are not too bad. Dry eyes/ watery eyes, drippy nose, possible nose bleeds. Otherwise fine. Other than the fatigue I found it easier than EC. I did work all the way through chemo. Check out the chemo club thread too - lots of tips on there!! You will get through it!!! 2 months on and it's like a bad dream!!
